questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with chest pain for the past hour. His ECG is shown. What is his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anteroseptal STEMI would present with ST-segment elevations in the precordial leads V1-V2, representing the anterior wall and ventricular septum supplied by the left anterior descending artery.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF indicate inferior STEMI, which typically results from occlusion of the right coronary artery.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterolateral STEMI would present with ST-segment elevations in leads V5-V6, representing the lateral wall of the left ventricle and cardiac apex supplied by the diagonal branches of the left anterior descending artery or left circumflex artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Lateral STEMI would present with ST-segment elevations in leads I and aVL, representing the lateral wall of the left ventricle typically supplied by the proximal left circumflex artery.

E) INCORRECT:

Posterior STEMI would present with ST-segment elevations in the posterior leads V7-V9, or may show reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1-V4 on a standard 12-lead ECG, representing the posterior wall of the left ventricle supplied by the posterior descending artery.

questions.text:
A 78 year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with lightheadedness for the past few hours. His rhythm strip is shown. What is his diagnosis?
His rhythm strip shows Atrioventricular (AV) dissociation: P waves and QRS complexes have regular but unrelated rhythms because there is no conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in some P waves being completely or partially buried in QRS complexes or T waves.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval greater than 200 ms with intact conduction from atria to ventricles. In first-degree AV block, all P waves are followed by QRS complexes, which is not seen on the presented rhythm strip.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Third-degree AV block represents complete electrical dissociation between the atria and ventricles with no conduction of impulses from the atria to the ventricles. This results in P waves and QRS complexes maintaining their own independent, regular rhythms with no relationship to each other as demonstrated on this patient's rhythm strip.

C) INCORRECT:

Mobitz I second-degree AV block is characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a beat is dropped, maintaining some relationship between P waves and QRS complexes. This rhythm strip demonstrates complete AV dissociation with independent atrial and ventricular rhythms, which is inconsistent with the periodic conduction seen in Mobitz I block.

D) INCORRECT:

Mobitz II second-degree AV block is characterized by intermittent nonconducted P waves with a constant PR interval, meaning some P waves are followed by QRS complexes while others are not. The rhythm strip shows complete AV dissociation with independent atrial and ventricular rhythms, which differs from Mobitz II block where partial conduction between atria and ventricles is maintained.

E) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation is characterized by irregularly irregular RR intervals and indiscernible P waves. The rhythm strip demonstrates discrete P waves with regular atrial activity and complete AV dissociation, which is inconsistent atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a family history of sudden cardiac death presents to the emergency department with an episode of syncope. His ECG is shown. What is his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wellens syndrome presents with characteristic T-wave abnormalities in the anterior leads, specifically biphasic T waves (with initial positive deflection) or symmetrical T-wave inversions in V2-V3, rather than the coved ST elevation pattern seen in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Anteroseptal STEMI typically manifests with classic ST elevation V1-V2 rather than the characteristic coved ST elevation pattern with pseudo-right bundle branch block morphology seen in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Pericarditis presents with characteristic diffuse (saddle-shaped) ST elevations throughout multiple leads and PR segment depressions, rather than the localized coved ST elevation pattern limited to V1 and V2 seen in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome demonstrates a preexcitation pattern with characteristic short PR interval, delta wave (slurred upstroke at the start of the QRS complex), and widened QRS complex, rather than the coved ST elevation pattern seen in this case.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Brugada syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant genetic channelopathy that manifests with characteristic pseudo-RBBB and coved ST elevation in leads V1–V3 as seen in this case. This condition presents predominantly in Asian men and is associated with syncope and increased risk of sudden cardiac death due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe palpitations and lightheadedness that started 30 minutes ago. She has had similar episodes in the past. Ten minutes after arrival, she is asymptomatic. Her current pulse is 64/min and blood pressure is 123/70 mm Hg . Physical examination shows warm extremities and palpable pulses. Electrocardiography (ECG) recorded at the time of admission is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's ECG findings?

choices.text: Ectopic arrhythmogenic foci within the ventricles
Two alternative conduction pathways within the atrioventricular node

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ectopic foci within the ventricles are the cause of ventricular premature beats (VPBs). VPBs are mostly harmless, but if they occur frequently, they can cause lightheadedness, dizziness, and palpitations, as seen in this patient. However, ECG in patients with VPBs typically shows QRS complexes with a block-like morphology and a subsequent compensatory pause.
Image Description:

ECG rhythm strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm (blue overlay: heart rate approx. 95 bpm; narrow QRS complexes) with frequent PVCs (monomorphic QRS complexes approx. 440 ms wide)
– Top strip: trigeminy (a repeating pattern of one PVC after every two sinus beats)
– Middle strip: two short runs of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT; yellow overlay: heart rate approx.150 bpm) and one PVC couplet (green overlay)
– Bottom strip: one short run of NSVT, two PVC couplets, and a fusion complex (red overlay)

B) CORRECT:

An accessory atrioventricular pathway , which connects the atria and ventricles and bypasses the AV node , is the pathomechanism of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, a type of atrioventricular reciprocating tachycardia . The accessory pathway results in preexcitation of the ventricles and intermittent tachycardia, which can then lead to palpitations, dizziness, chest pain, dyspnea, and syncope. Preexcitation is discernible on ECG as a shortened PR interval ; the subsequent myocardial conduction can cause a slurred upstroke in the QRS complex called a delta wave . This finding is not seen in all patients with WPW.

WPW is a type of antidromic atrioventricular reciprocating tachycardia. In the case of an orthodromic AVRT, the QRS complex is narrow, followed by a P wave (retrograde in leads II, III, aVF), and lacks delta waves.

Key learning point: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is caused by an accessory atrioventricular conduction pathway that leads to ventricular preexcitation and characteristic ECG findings such as a short PR interval and delta waves.
Image Description:

Conduction pathways and characteristic ECG findings in normal impulse transmission and in WPW syndrome. Note that the condition is referred to as WPW syndrome only if the characteristic ECG findings are present and the patient is also symptomatic or there is evidence of arrhythmia; if the characteristic ECG findings are present without these additional features, the condition is referred to as “WPW pattern.”

Left (normal impulse transmission and normal ECG findings): PR interval 120–200 ms; QRS duration < 100 ms

Right (WPW impulse transmission and characteristic ECG findings): short PR interval < 120 ms; slurred upstroke (delta wave) at the start of the QRS complex with widened QRS ≥ 120 ms

C) INCORRECT:

Acute pulmonary artery occlusion (ie, pulmonary embolism) can manifest with sudden-onset palpitations, shortness of breath, tachycardia, and in severe cases, syncope. However, sudden improvement, as seen in this patient, is atypical of pulmonary embolism, which often leads to cardiogenic shock if left untreated. Characteristic ECG signs include right-axis deviation , a marked S wave in lead I , and a marked Q wave in lead III (S I Q III type). Pulmonary embolism does not cause delta waves.

D) INCORRECT:

Two alternative conduction pathways (one fast and one slow) within the atrioventricular node are the cause of atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). AVNRT is characterized by narrow QRS complexes and an invisible P wave (which is buried within the QRS complex), neither of which is seen on this patient's ECG.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular rhythm; heart rate approx. 180/min.
– Normal cardiac axis
– Narrow QRS complexes (< 100 ms)
– No visible P waves (these are buried in the QRS complexes)
– Minimal ST depression, most noticeably in lead I
– QRS alternans: QRS amplitude is normal throughout but oscillates (best seen in rhythm strip at bottom of image; indicated by green line)

The characteristic ECG features of AVNRT are a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia without visible P-waves. QRS alternans is more characteristic of atrioventricular reciprocating tachycardia (AVRT), but may also be present in AVNRT.

E) INCORRECT:

Rare congenital anomalies of potassium channels are associated with long QT syndrome, which can cause palpitations, dizziness, and syncope. Patients with long QT syndrome are typically asymptomatic; however, in severe cases, life-threatening arrhythmias can occur (eg, torsades de pointes). Congenital potassium channelopathies do not cause delta waves.
questions.hint: This patient's electrocardiography shows sinus rhythm with short PR intervals and delta waves, consistent with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome .
